raw_text:
Looks and music to drive mobiles
 
 Mobile phones are still enjoying a boom time in sales, according to research from technology analysts Gartner.
 
 More than 674 million mobiles were sold last year globally, said the report, the highest total sold to date. The figure was 30% more than in 2003 and surpassed even the most optimistic predictions, Gartner said. Good design and the look of a mobile, as well as new services such as music downloads, could go some way to pushing up sales in 2005, said analysts. Although people were still looking for better replacement phones, there was evidence, according to Gartner, that some markets were seeing a slow-down in replacement sales.
 
 "All the markets grew apart from Japan which shows that replacement sales are continuing in western Europe," mobile analyst Carolina Milanesi told the BBC News website. "Japan is where north America and western European markets can be in a couple of years' time. "They already have TV, music, ringtones, cameras, and all that we can think of on mobiles, so people have stopped buying replacement phones."
 
 But there could be a slight slowdown in sales in European and US markets too, according to Gartner, as people wait to see what comes next in mobile technology. This means mobile companies have to think carefully about what they are offering in new models so that people see a compelling reason to upgrade, said Gartner. Third generation mobiles (3G) with the ability to handle large amounts of data transfer, like video, could drive people into upgrading their phones, but Ms Milanesi said it was difficult to say how quickly that would happen. "At the end of the day, people have cameras and colour screens on mobiles and for the majority of people out there who don't really care about technology the speed of data to a phone is not critical." Nor would the rush to produce two or three megapixel camera phones be a reason for mobile owners to upgrade on its own. The majority of camera phone models are not at the stage where they can compete with digital cameras which also have flashes and zooms.
 
 More likely to drive sales in 2005 would be the attention to design and aesthetics, as well as music services. The Motorola Razr V3 phone was typical of the attention to design that would be more commonplace in 2005, she added. This was not a "women's thing", she said, but a desire from men and women to have a gadget that is a form of self-expression too. It was not just about how the phone functioned, but about what it said about its owner. "Western Europe has always been a market which is quite attentive to design," said Ms Milanesi.
 
 "People are after something that is nice-looking, and together with that, there is the entertainment side. "This year music will have a part to play in this." The market for full-track music downloads was worth just $20 million (£10.5 million) in 2004, but is set to be worth $1.8 billion (£94 million) by 2009, according to Juniper Research. Sony Ericsson just released its Walkman branded mobile phone, the W800, which combines a digital music player with up to 30 hours' battery life, and a two megapixel camera. In July last year, Motorola and Apple announced a version of iTunes online music downloading service would be released which would be compatible with Motorola mobile phones. Apple said the new iTunes music player would become Motorola's standard music application for its music phones. But the challenge will be balancing storage capacity with battery life if mobile music hopes to compete with digital music players like the iPod. Ms Milanesi said more models would likely be released in the coming year with hard drives. But they would be more likely to compete with the smaller capacity music players that have around four gigabyte storage capacity, which would not put too much strain on battery life.
llama3.2:1b: Mobile phones sold over 674 million last year globally, a 30% increase from 2003 and surpassing predictions.
Design and music services are key drivers of sales, with good looks and new services like music downloads helping to boost demand.
Some markets, such as Japan and Western Europe, have seen slower replacement sales due to the availability of other electronic devices.
However, these markets may see a return in two to three years' time when they can no longer keep up with newer technology.
Gartner analysts predict that third-generation mobile phones with large data transfer capabilities will drive demand for upgrades.
While camera phone models are not yet competitive with digital cameras, design and music services will be more important drivers of sales in 2005.
llama3.2:3b: Mobile phone sales reached 674 million globally last year, a 30% increase from 2003, driven by good design and new services like music downloads.
Replacement sales are slowing down in Western Europe, while Japan is already saturated with features like TV, music, and cameras, leading to reduced upgrade demand.
The focus will be on balancing storage capacity with battery life for mobile music players.
gemma2:2b: Mobile phone sales reached record levels in 2004, driven by design aesthetics and services like music downloads.
While replacement sales remain strong in some markets, Gartner suggests a possible slowdown in the near future as people wait for technological advancements.
Features like 3G connectivity are expected to drive upgrades, but the pace of adoption is uncertain.
Music services are another key driver, with companies incorporating dedicated digital players into their devices.
Focus on aesthetics and design will likely continue to play a major role in attracting consumers.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Mobile phones continue to sell well, especially in Japan.
Good design and new services like music downloads could boost sales.
Market growth may slow down, but third-generation mobiles can handle data transfer better than current models.
People are mostly interested in phones with camera functions for self-expression.
Mobile phones are expected to be more important in 2005 due to their attractive aesthetics.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Mobile phone sales reached a record high of 674 million units last year globally, up 30% from 2003 and surpassing earlier predictions.
Design and music services are expected to boost mobile sales in 2005 despite ongoing interest in new replacement phones.
Third-generation mobiles with data capabilities may drive upgrades sooner.
Design focus is on self-expression, while music remains a key factor for growth.
Market attention shifts from functionality to design aesthetics and entertainment features.
Music downloads grow significantly over time.
Sony Ericsson introduces a combined digital music player and camera phone.
Hard drives will likely be added to mobile phones in the future, aiming to compete with larger storage devices without compromising battery life.
qwen2.5:3b: Mobile phones continue to sell well globally, with 674 million sold last year, surpassing previous records.
Improved design and new services like music downloads are driving sales in 2005.
However, Japan shows a continued trend of replacement sales for mobiles due to saturation of features such as cameras, TV, ringtones, and music.
Sales growth is expected to slow down in Europe and US markets as people wait for the next technological advancement.
Third-generation mobiles with data transfer capabilities might push upgrades.
Design aesthetics and music services are more likely to drive sales in 2005.

Sony Ericsson’s Walkman-branded phone and Apple's integration of iTunes into Motorola phones exemplify this trend, though storage capacity versus battery life is a concern for full-capacity music downloads on mobiles.
opencoder:1.5b: The key idea in this summary is to focus on the growth of mobile sales while highlighting key moments like Gartner's analysis about European and US markets slow-downs and their impact on mobile phone sales.
The overall strategy involves a focus on design, aesthetics, and music services.

The first thing that will be discussed is how people wait in the tech industry before they start upgrading their phones; Ms Milanesi adds to this by suggesting that people will need to think about what makes a phone unique and appealing for them.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary is concise and focuses on key ideas:

1.
Looks and music to drive mobiles: This is a key driver of sales in 2005 as people look for better design and new services like music downloads.
Good design and the look of a mobile, as well as new services like music downloads, could go some way to pushing up sales in 2005.
The market is growing rapidly: There was evidence that replacement sales were continuing in 2003 but there was also a slowdown in sales in 2004 and 2005.

Good design and the look of a mobile, as well as new services like music downloads, could drive up sales in 2005: This is not just about how the phone functions, but about what it says about its owner.
The market for full-track music downloading will be worth $1.8 billion by 2009: This is a significant increase from the current market size of around $100 million in 2004.
Apple and Motorola are likely to release new versions of their mobile phones with improved storage capacity: This could help to compete with digital music players like the iPod.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Mobile phones saw significant sales growth, with Gartner reporting over 674 million units sold globally last year, up 30% compared to 2003.
Design, aesthetics, and new services like music downloads played key roles in driving these sales.
However, preferences for personal ownership led some markets in Western Europe to see slower replacement sales as people favor owning their devices.
In 2005, third generation mobiles (3G) with data transfer capabilities were expected to drive sales if they supported quality or video use.
The preference for cameras on phones was also notable but not crucial unless storage capacity reached a high level.
Camera phone models were mostly small and didn't compete much with digital cameras.
Notable examples of designs from 2005 included the Razr V3, which focused on design, and the W800 by Sony Ericsson, combining a music player with camera features, aimed at appeal to tech enthusiasts.
tinyllama:1.1b: The global mobile phone market is set for a sluggish growth in 2005 due to concerns over replacement sales and increased competition from new markets.

However, the emergence of multimedia phones with attractive design and image enhancements could drive sales, particularly among users who are more attuned to design and self-expression through their mobile devices.
The boom in sales of third generation (3G) models with larger memory capacities, video recording capabilities, and mobile web access would also contribute to the growth of the market.

Furthermore, music downloads via mobile phones and other digital services such as iTuens could become more widely available, helping to balance the need for storage capacity while balancing battery life in new devices.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The rapid growth of mobile phones has been driven by numerous factors such as increased competition in the market and user expectations that technology continues to meet, according to Gartner analysts.
More than 674 million mobiles were sold globally last year, with the highest total sold being in 2003, surpassing even the most optimistic projections from Gartner.

According to analysts, these high sales figures are a result of several factors:

1.

Aesthetic appeal: Mobile phones have increasingly focused on design and appearance, with manufacturers and marketers investing in flashy features such as color screens and cameras that can handle large amounts of data transfer.
This has driven up the sales figures for these gadgets.

Music services: The rise in music downloads is another factor that has contributed to the popularity of mobile phones, with companies like Sony Ericsson releasing new models with built-in music players.

Compatibility with other devices: Innovations such as third-generation (3G) networks have enabled mobile phones to connect with a wide range of compatible devices, further increasing their value and attractiveness for users.
Technological advancements: The rapid proliferation of digital cameras and other technologies has also driven up the sales figures of mobile phones.
As these gadgets become more ubiquitous, consumers are more likely to upgrade their phones on an annual basis.
Consumer preferences: According to Gartner analysts, the US is the market that seems most receptive to this technology trend, with Western Europe and Japan following suit.
Mobile companies have a tough job of matching these expectations while simultaneously adapting their products to fit into consumers' changing needs.
Global demand: As mobile phones become an integral part of people’s lives around the world, Gartner analysts predict global sales will continue to grow in the years ahead.
However, this growth could be slowed by factors such as the development of new markets and the need for more advanced replacement models that can handle larger amounts of data transfer.
In conclusion, mobile phone sales have been driven by numerous factors, including increased competition and user expectations that technology continues to meet.
The rapid growth of mobile phones is a result of a combination of factors that are shaping the market in exciting new ways.
phi:2.7b: Gartner research shows that mobile phone sales are still booming, with over 670 million sold last year globally, surpassing even the most optimistic predictions.
Good design and services like music downloads may increase sales in 2005, but replacements for old phones are becoming less important.
There is expected to be a slight slowdown in European and US markets as people wait for new mobile technology.
Mobile phone companies must consider offering compelling reasons for upgrading.

While 3G phones with large data transfer capabilities could drive upgrades, the focus will likely be on design, aesthetics, and music services like downloading full-track music for $1.8 billion by 2009.
orca-mini:3b: Mobile phones are enjoying a boom time in sales according to research from technology analysts Gartner.
More than 674 million mobiles were sold last year globally, the highest total sold to date.
Analysts predict that some markets may be seeing a slow-down in replacement sales, but there is evidence that some markets are still growing.
Mobile companies have to think carefully about what they are offering in new models to encourage people to upgrade.
Third generation mobiles (3G) with the ability to handle large amounts of data transfer like video could drive people into upgrading their phones.
The majority of camera phone models are not at the stage where they can compete with digital cameras which also have flashes and zooms.
Attention to design and aesthetics, as well as music services, could drive sales in 2005.
Mobile phones are still a form of self-expression, and people are after something that is nice-looking.
Music will have a part to play in this year's market.
The challenge will be balancing storage capacity with battery life if mobile music hopes to compete with digital music players like the iPod.

More models are likely to be released in the coming year with hard drives but they will be more likely to compete with smaller capacity music players that have around four gigabyte storage capacity, which would not put too much strain on battery life.
hermes3:3b: Mobile sales boom; design, music services key for upgrades.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Gartner reported over 674 million mobile phone sales in 2004, a 30% increase from 2003 and surpassing expectations.
Good design, new services like music downloads, and attention to aesthetics are factors that could boost sales in 2005.

Mobile analyst Carolina Milanesi noted that markets like Japan demonstrate a slowdown in replacement sales, while European and US markets may also experience a slight slowdown due to people waiting for future mobile technology developments.
Third generation (3G) mobiles with enhanced data transfer capabilities could drive upgrades; however, for the majority of users, the speed of data isn't critical.
Design and aesthetics, as well as music services, are likely drivers of sales in 2005, with the market for full-track music downloads expected to grow significantly by 2009.

Sony Ericsson's Walkman mobile phone, released in 2004, combined a digital music player with up to 30 hours' battery life and a 2 megapixel camera, while Motorola and Apple announced a version of iTunes compatible with Motorola phones that same year.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Mobile phone sales reached a record 674 million units in 2004, growing 30% from 2003, according to Gartner.
While replacement sales continued in Western Europe, Japan saw a slowdown as consumers already had advanced features like TV, music, and cameras.
A similar trend could emerge in Europe and the US, prompting mobile companies to focus on compelling upgrades.
While 3G and high-megapixel cameras may not drive immediate upgrades, design and music services are expected to boost sales in 2005.
Stylish models like the Motorola Razr V3 and music-enabled phones, such as Sony Ericsson’s Walkman W800 and Motorola’s iTunes-compatible devices, highlight this trend.
The mobile music market, worth $20 million in 2004, is projected to grow to $1.8 billion by 2009, though battery life and storage capacity remain challenges for competing with digital music players.
stablelm2:1.6b: Gartner's research reveals that over a million mobile phones were sold globally last year, surpassing previous sales records and demonstrating strong design and new service appeal.
Western Europe is particularly attentive to aesthetics with replacement sales in western European markets showing evidence of a slow-down.
Third-generation (3G) 4G capable phones are expected to drive upgrades, but the focus remains on attention to design and music services rather than camera capabilities.
The market for full-track music downloads was worth $2 million (£1.5 million) in 2004; by 2009 it's projected at $1.8 billion.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Mobile phone sales reached 674 million globally in 2004, marking a 30% increase from 2003 and the highest total to date, according to Gartner.
This growth was attributed to improved design, new services like music downloads, and growing demand for mobiles as digital hubs for various functions such as cameras, photography, and entertainment.
Japan and western Europe displayed a slowdown in replacement phone sales due to extensive existing features on mobiles.
However, the market for 3G technology could boost upgrades by supporting high-definition video.
Despite this, Gartner predicts a potential slowdown in European and US markets as consumers wait for advancements in mobile tech.
Design and aesthetics will be key drivers in 2005, with an emphasis on making phones attractive forms of self-expression.
Music services are expected to play a significant role, with the market for full-track music downloads projected to reach $1.8 billion by 2009.
Sony Ericsson's Walkman-branded W800 and Motorola's iTunes integration demonstrate this trend, offering combined digital music players and camera functionality.
The challenge lies in balancing storage capacity with battery life for competitive mobile music devices to rival digital music players like the iPod.
Gartner anticipates more 32GB or higher-capacity models in 2005 to address this issue.
